questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characters were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is caused by the presence of only one X chromosome (45XO karyotype). The key features of Turner syndrome include:

 

  • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short.
  • Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome.
  • Webbed neck (common feature).

 

Note - 46XXX: This karyotype, also known as triple X syndrome, typically presents with taller than average stature and normal sexual development, which does not match the described clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The karyotype 45XO is associated with Turner syndrome, which is characterized by delayed puberty, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, widely spaced nipples, and other distinctive physical features.

choices.text: 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a
1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c
1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b
1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Matched Pairs:

 

  • 1-b: Collarette scales - Pityriasis Rosea: Collarette scales are characteristic of Pityriasis Rosea, where these scales are fine, peripherally attached but centrally detached, often found around the edge of the herald patch or subsequent lesions.
  • 2-c: Silvery scales - Psoriasis: Silvery scales are hallmark features of Psoriasis. These scales are typically seen as thick, shiny, and silvery white, indicative of excessive proliferation of skin layers, particularly due to parakeratosis.
  • 3-d: Mica-like scales - Pityriasis lichenoides chronica: Mica-like scales in Pityriasis lichenoides chronica refer to the fine, adherent scales that resemble mineral mica, found on polymorphic lesions that can also show hemorrhagic crusting.
  • 4-a: Branny scales - Pityriasis versicolor: Branny scales are a feature of Pityriasis versicolor, described as fine, powdery, and often easily detachable, much like bran. These scales highlight the superficial fungal infection's impact on the skin.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Diseases & special scales:

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 4.13, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Image 1- Influenza viruses have linear segmented, single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Image 2- Adenovirus is an icosahedroal symmetry with fibres extruding from vertices and contains double-stranded DNA.

 

 

Image 4 - Corona virus is non-segmented single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Coronavirus Structure

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filoviruses, such as Ebola and Marburg, are filamentous and contain nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

  • This is an azole antifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.

 

Option C. Ciclopirox olamine:

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.

 

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

Tioconazole is another azole antifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Reference - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page no 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: A patient with multiple skin tumors presented to OPD, further workup revealed defective DNA repair due to double strand break. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Xeroderma pigmentosum

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair (NER), which is essential for repairing DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light. Patients with XP are unable to effectively repair DNA damage, leading to the accumulation of mutations in skin cells, particularly following exposure to UV light. This defect in DNA repair results in a high propensity for developing multiple skin tumors, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and malignant melanoma. The key point is the "defective DNA repair due to double strand break," which directly correlates with the genetic defect seen in XP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: Although Bloom syndrome also involves a defect in DNA repair, it is more commonly associated with hematological malignancies like lymphoma and leukemia, rather than skin tumors. Patients typically present with a predisposition to developing blood-related cancers (lymphoma, leukemia) rather than solid tumors on the skin.

 

Option C. Cockayne’s syndrome: Cockayne syndrome is associated with photosensitivity and growth problems in children, but it is not associated with the development of malignancies, including skin tumors.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is primarily associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and other internal malignancies, but it is not associated with skin tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair, leading to a high risk of developing multiple skin tumors due to the inability to repair DNA damage caused by UV light exposure.

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ecological

 

In the given study, the unit of study is the population, and the data collected by the investigator is secondary in nature. Therefore, this type of study is an ecological study, also known as a correlational study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-Sectional Study: Involves collecting data at a single point in time from individuals to assess the prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

  • The unit of analysis is the individual, not the population.

 

Option C. Experimental Study: Involves the researcher manipulating one or more variables to observe the effect on an outcome.

 

  • There is no experimental intervention in the given study scenario.

 

Option D. Quasi-Experimental Study: Involves an intervention but lacks random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

 

  • Similar to experimental studies, quasi-experimental studies involve individuals, not population-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY

 

  • Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

choices.text: FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <70%
FEV1/FVC<0.7 and FEV1< 50%
Both A and C

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?(NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger). This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles Involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus,  Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis: These muscles flex the wrist.

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

 

The muscle marked in the image, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension (Incorrect): Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion. It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx. The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension. Muscles Involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus , Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction (Incorrect): Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction. Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself

 

Option D. Abduction (Incorrect): Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction. The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals are essential for the flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, contributing significantly to the dexterity and functional complexity of the hand, particularly in actions that require a combination of flexing and extending different joints of the fingers, such as typing or playing certain musical instruments.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: Vaccine can be prepared against which of the following proteins of the virus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

The L1 protein of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a major capsid protein and is the primary antigen used in the development of HPV vaccines. L1 proteins can self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) which mimic the natural virus structure but do not contain viral DNA, making them non-infectious. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response, providing protection against HPV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6 and E7 proteins: These are oncogenes of HPV responsible for cellular transformation and promoting oncogenesis. These proteins drive cell cycle allowing genome amplification in upper epithelial layers and degrade tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and pRb. They are not used for vaccine preparation as they do not induce a protective immune response.

 

Option C. E1 and E2 proteins: These are involved in viral replication and transcription regulation. E1 acts as an origin binding protein and ATPase-dependent helicase, while E2 regulates viral gene transcription and is associated with E1 for viral genome partitioning. They are not targets for the current vaccines.

 

Option D. DE3: This option is not relevant to HPV proteins in the context of vaccine development.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with C/O muscle weakness came to OPD. Doctor found he has cardiomyopathy & diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiolipin

 

Barth syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by mutations in gene responsible for the production of an enzyme involved in cardiolipin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lecithin is a common phospholipid found in various tissues and cell membranes, but it is not specifically associated with Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option C. Lysolecithin is a derivative of lecithin that is formed when lecithin is hydrolyzed. It is not directly related to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option D. Cephalin is a term that refers to a group of phospholipids present in cell membranes, but it is not specifically linked to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a crucial role in maintaining mitochondrial structure and function.
  • The defective cardiolipin affects several mitochondrial processes, including energy production, electron transport chain function, and mitochondrial membrane stability. 
  • C/f
    • Muscle weakness
    • Neutropenia
    • Cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The given patient presenting symptoms that indicate diffuse systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis/polymyositis, is highly probable to have an overlap syndrome [Combinations of three connective tissue diseases, i.e., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)].

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are characteristically found in patients with overlap syndromes, which involve features of systemic sclerosis combined with polymyositis or dermatomyositis. These overlap syndromes involve a combination of autoimmune conditions, often including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS), and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Anti-U3 RNP antibodies are typically associated with systemic sclerosis but can be found in both limited and diffuse forms of the disease. They are not specifically linked to the overlap syndrome seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), not the diffuse form or the overlap syndrome involving myositis.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are strongly associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, particularly with lung involvement, but they are less common than Anti-PM-Scl antibodies in patients with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which requires routine coagulation profile monitoring. The standard test used for monitoring Lepirudin is the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). In cath labs, when administering in high doses need to be monitor with ACT (Activated Clotting Time) rather than aPTT.

 

This is necessary to ensure the correct therapeutic range is maintained and to avoid complications such as bleeding.

 

Note - There are four parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors: lepirudin, hirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It has a predictable anticoagulant effect, and routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required under standard clinical circumstances. In special situations, monitoring can be done using anti-factor Xa levels.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux, like Enoxaparin, does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. In specific clinical scenarios, anti-factor Xa levels may be measured.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is classified under direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Routine coagulation monitoring is not required due to its reliable and predictable effects. However, if monitoring is needed, aPTT can be used, though more specific tests like the dilute thrombin time (dTT) or the ecarin clotting time (ECT) are preferred for accurate measurement.

 

Note - There are four DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants): Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor), Apixaban, Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban (all 3 are factor Xa inhibitor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin proteins are an example of? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Transport protein


Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are all examples of molecular motor proteins that play critical roles in cellular transport mechanisms.

 

  • Kinesin: This motor protein moves along microtubules in cells, transporting various cellular cargoes, such as organelles, vesicles, and proteins, from the center of the cell (soma) towards the periphery (axon terminal) in an anterograde direction.
  • Dynein: This motor protein also moves along microtubules but in the opposite direction, transporting cargo from the periphery back to the center of the cell in a retrograde direction.
  • Myosin: This motor protein interacts with actin filaments and is involved in a variety of cellular movements, including muscle contraction and intracellular cargo transport.

 

These proteins are not involved in cell membrane structure, adhesion of cell organelles, or forming intercellular junctions. Their primary function is to facilitate intracellular transport, making them key components of cellular logistics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane protein: These are proteins that are part of or interact with the cell membrane, such as receptors and ion channels.

 

Option C. Cell organelle adherent protein: These proteins help maintain the structure and position of organelles within the cell. Ex: catenin and cadherin

 

Option D. Intercellular junctional protein: These are proteins that form connections between cells, such as connexins in gap junctions or occludins in tight junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are transport proteins essential for intracellular cargo movement along cytoskeletal filaments.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: What is the recommended time gap between the application of two live vaccines? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4 weeks

 

  • According to the guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO), there should be a minimum interval of 4 weeks (28 days) between the administration of two live vaccines.
  • This is to ensure that the immune system has enough time to respond to each vaccine and generate an adequate immune response without interference from the other vaccine.
  • Two live vaccines otherwise can be given together on the same day

 

Educational Objective:

 

General rules for multiple vaccine administration: –

 

  • 2 live vaccines can be given together
  • Live and killed vaccines can be given together
  • Cholera vaccine and Yellow fever vaccine cannot be given together
  • OPV is a live vaccine where single dose is not sufficient for immunization
  • 2 live vaccines can be administered simultaneously at different sites (or at an interval of 4 weeks)

questions.text:
A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Bemepedoic acid
  2. Ezetimibe
  3. Gemfibrozil
  4. Evolocumab
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Explanation: 


The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:

 

1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis

 

2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption

 

4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.

 

Other Option: 
 

3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective: 
 

Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: Name the hormone secreted by the marked cell: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitonin

 

The marked cells in the histology image are parafollicular cells, also known as C cells, located in the thyroid gland. These cells are found outside the thyroid follicles, which are filled with colloid. Parafollicular cells are responsible for secreting the hormone calcitonin.

 

Calcitonin plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis by lowering blood calcium levels when they are too high. It achieves this by inhibiting osteoclast activity in bones, which decreases the release of calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline: Adrenaline is secreted by the adrenal medulla, not by the cells in the thyroid gland. Therefore, it is not related to the marked cells in the image.

 

Option C. Prolactin: Prolactin is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and is involved in milk production in the mammary glands. It is not secreted by the thyroid gland or its parafollicular cells.

 

Option D. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is secreted by the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not the parafollicular cells. The marked cells in the image are outside the follicles and are responsible for calcitonin secretion, not thyroxine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parafollicular cells (C cells) in the thyroid gland secrete calcitonin, a hormone that helps regulate calcium levels in the blood.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between height and weight in a specific population. She decides to utilize a cluster sampling method to streamline the data collection process. After analyzing data from four distinct clusters, each one consistently demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight. Based on this information, what can the researcher expect about the overall correlation coefficient when combining data from all four clusters? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Equal to 0.6

 

  • When each cluster independently shows a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight, the overall correlation coefficient for the combined data will also be 0.6.
  • This is because the correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, and consistent values across clusters will result in the same overall correlation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCATTER/DOT DIAGRAM

 

  • Also known as ‘Correlation diagram
  • Is used to depict ‘correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables
  • Vertical axis in scatter diagram: should be the dependent or the outcome variable
  • In a scatter diagram, 2 imaginary lines are drawn along the distribution of dots/ scatter.

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the most common causative organism for verruca vulgaris? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Human papillomavirus-2

 

  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected with common warts.
  • Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

Common warts typically have no symptoms. They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Treatment:

 

Topical – Salicylic acid, formalin, caustics etc.

 

Other:

 

  • Laser
  • Cryotherapy
  • Surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human papillomavirus-3 (HPV-3): While HPV-3 is a strain of the virus that can cause warts, it is not the predominant strain for verruca vulgaris.

 

Option B. Human papillomavirus-7 (HPV-7):

  • HPV-7 is associated with butcher's warts, which are common among meat handlers.
  • This strain is not the primary one responsible for the verruca vulgaris seen in the general population.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1): HPV-1 is mainly responsible for plantar warts, which appear on the soles of the feet as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • It is not the primary strain for verruca vulgaris on the hands and fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human papillomavirus-2 is the most common cause of verruca vulgaris (common warts), which is important for understanding the etiology and guiding treatment options for these lesions.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 25, Page no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 19, Page no 401

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

choices.text: Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse
Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins
Continue CPR till pulse is back

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is undergoing CPR. He is pulseless and shows the below ECG. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins

 

The ECG shown in the image is indicative of ventricular tachycardia . Pulseless VT is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate defibrillation. The appropriate treatment for VT during CPR is to deliver an unsynchronized shock (defibrillation) at an initial dose of 2 J/kg. After delivering the shock, it is crucial to immediately resume CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm and pulse, as this maximizes the chances of successful resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse: This option is incorrect because checking the pulse immediately after delivering the shock wastes valuable time. The correct protocol is to immediately resume CPR after the shock, without pausing to check the pulse, as this enhances the likelihood of restoring circulation.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is used for treating certain types of arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or atrial fibrillation (AF), but it is not appropriate for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In pulseless VT , unsynchronized defibrillation is required.

 

Option D. Continue CPR till pulse is back: This option is partially correct but incomplete. While continuing CPR is essential, the most crucial intervention in the case of pulseless VT is defibrillation. Without delivering a shock, the chances of survival are significantly diminished.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pediatric cardiac arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the ECG, the correct immediate action is to defibrillate with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing.

questions.text: Identify the image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

 

The image provided likely shows a neonate with a congenital defect characterized by the intestines and other abdominal organs extending outside of the abdominal cavity but contained within a sac composed of peritoneum and amnion. 

 

This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where the intestines, liver, and occasionally other organs remain outside of the abdomen in a sac because of a failure in the normal return of intestines and other contents back to the abdominal cavity during development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urachal cyst: This is a remnant of the embryonic connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord, which usually closes before birth. A cyst can form if this connection does not close properly. It typically does not involve protrusion of abdominal contents.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with cyst: This option isn't a standard term in medical diagnosis. An omphalocele does not typically have a cyst, but rather a sac that is formed from the peritoneum and amnion, containing the herniated organs.

 

Option D. Umbilical adenoma: This is not a recognized condition related to abdominal wall defects in neonates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Omphalocele is a birth defect characterized by an abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal contents into an overlying sac due to a failure of normal return of contents during embryonic development.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario presented here is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is caused by a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, denoted as 3.

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together using the mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

 

Other features that may be associated with DiGeorge syndrome include developmental delays, learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders. Treatment usually involves managing the individual symptoms and providing support to address any developmental or behavioral challenges

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1 - first pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, primarily associated with the development of structures like the middle ear and Eustachian tube.

 

Option B (2 - second pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, related to formations such as the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D (4 - fourth pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, although related to the development of superior parathyroid glands, it is not primarily responsible for the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands like the third pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

 

 

The third pharyngeal pouch's proper development is crucial for the normal formation of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Disruption in this development can lead to significant clinical symptoms like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, emphasizing the need for genetic testing and comprehensive clinical management in affected individuals.

questions.text: In a recent community health survey in Rajasthan, India, there has been a significant surge in cases of oral and lung cancers. It was found that tobacco consumption, both smoking and chewing, was a significant contributor. The government implemented legislation to curb tobacco use. This action is an example of which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary

 

The introduction of an Act to prevent the use of tobacco in community is an example of primary prevention, as it prevents the disease by bringing about a change of lifestyle, that is the use of tobacco as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial:

 

  • Prevents the development of risk factors.
  • Example: Legislation to reduce tobacco use, promoting healthy lifestyles from a young age to prevent the development of harmful habits.

 

Option C. Secondary:

 

  • Involves early detection and prompt intervention to prevent progression.
  • For example, screening programs like Pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tertiary:

 

  • Involves managing and reducing the impact of an ongoing illness.
  • For example, providing cardiac rehabilitation after a heart attack to prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Level of Prevention:

 

  • Primordial - Prevention of development of risk factors
  • Primary - Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • Secondary - Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • Tertiary - Complications are present, death is being prevented.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ampulla:

 

  • The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the most common site for fertilization.
  • This region provides an optimal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum and for the subsequent fertilization process to occur.
  • The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.

 

Structure of the Fallopian Tube:

 

The fallopian tube has four main parts:

 

  1. Infundibulum: The funnel-shaped opening near the ovary with finger-like projections called fimbriae.
  2. Ampulla: The widest and longest part where fertilization typically occurs.
  3. Isthmus: A narrow section adjacent to the uterus.
  4. Interstitial (or intramural): The part that traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrow section of the fallopian tube close to the uterus. While it plays a role in the transport of the fertilized egg to the uterus, it is not the primary site for fertilization.

 

Option C. Interstitial: This portion of the fallopian tube traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity. It is not typically where fertilization occurs.

 

Option D. Infundibular: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary, equipped with fimbriae to help capture the released ovum. Fertilization does not typically occur here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which is the widest and longest part of the tube.

 

Ref: Page no 23, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia 

 

Unlike hypokalemia, hyperkalemia is not typically associated with re-feeding syndrome. Instead, rapid re-feeding may lead to increased insulin secretion, which drives potassium into cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Re-feeding syndrome can lead to hypokalemia due to increased cellular uptake of potassium during the anabolic phase, especially if there is concomitant insulin administration.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Re-feeding syndrome can cause hypocalcemia due to decreased parathyroid hormone secretion and subsequent impaired bone resorption, leading to low serum calcium levels.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Re-feeding syndrome is characterized by rapid shifts of phosphate into cells during the anabolic phase, leading to hypophosphatemia, which can manifest clinically as weakness, respiratory failure, and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients at risk of re-feeding syndrome, electrolyte imbalances such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia are commonly observed, while hyperkalemia is typically not associated with this condition.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burn Marshall

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is a technique used during breech deliveries. This maneuver involves gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen by holding the baby's ankles. The purpose is to facilitate the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation. It requires careful handling to avoid neck injury and to maintain control during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wigand: The Wigand maneuver is another technique used in obstetrics, but it is not related to breech delivery or involves swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen.

 

Option C. Mauriceau Smellie Viet: This maneuver is used during breech delivery but involves supporting the baby's body on the obstetrician's forearm with the index and middle fingers placed on the maxilla to flex the head. It does not involve swinging the baby and is distinct from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Option D. Prague: The Prague maneuver is used in breech delivery, specifically when the baby's arms are extended above the head. The obstetrician rotates the baby to facilitate arm delivery before the head, differing from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is characterized by gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman discovers a well-defined, mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 2.5 x 6 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario describes a young female with a well-defined, mobile lump in the breast, which is characteristic of a breast mouse or fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that typically present as freely mobile masses in young women. They consist of an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma. Depending on the arrangement of the fibrous tissue, fibroadenomas can be classified as pericanalicular or intracanalicular subtypes. Notably, the use of the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporine has been associated with an increased risk of developing fibroadenomas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ), Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma, and Option D. Intraductal papilloma are all malignant or precancerous lesions that would typically present with additional signs such as skin dimpling, nipple retraction, or ulceration, rather than as a mobile, painless lump in a young woman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are the most common cause of benign, mobile breast lumps in young women. They are characterized by an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma and may be associated with the use of cyclosporine.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). Although Atomoxetine is the first-line SNRI approved for the treatment of ADHD, Reboxetine is the next best option available.

 

Reboxetine works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, thereby increasing its levels in the synaptic cleft. While Reboxetine is not commonly used for ADHD and is not specifically approved for this condition, it has been used off-label for the treatment of ADHD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is primarily a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. It is not selective for norepinephrine alone and is one of the most commonly prescribed medications for ADHD, but it does not fit the criteria of a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, not a reuptake inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of ADHD, but its mechanism of action is different from that of a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option D. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant-like drug used primarily for narcolepsy and other sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and does not have a primary role in ADHD treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for the treatment of ADHD, although it is not the first-line treatment. Atomoxetine is the preferred NRI for ADHD, but in its absence, Reboxetine is the next best option among the given choices.

questions.text: In which container will you dispose of the needle with the syringe after vaccination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White

 

Explanation:

 

The needle of the syringe, being a metallic and sharp component, should be disposed of in the white container after vaccination. The needle, being a sharp waste, goes into the white container, which is specifically designated for disposing of sharp and metallic waste.

 

After proper treatment methods like autoclaving, dry heat destruction, shredding, or mutilation, the contents of the white container are sent to iron foundries, sharp pits, or landfills for final disposal.

 

Plastic component of syringe – in Red container

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital syphilis

 

Explanation:

 

Kassowitz's rule pertains to congenital syphilis. According to this rule, if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the likelihood of congenital syphilis affecting the fetus in later pregnancies decreases. This phenomenon is observed as a result of the immune system's adaptive response and potential changes in the transmission dynamics of the infection over successive pregnancies. Therefore, the rule suggests that with each subsequent pregnancy, the outcome for the fetus improves if the infection remains untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary syphilis: Primary syphilis involves the initial chancre or ulcer at the site of infection and is not related to Kassowitz's rule, which specifically addresses outcomes in congenital syphilis.

 

Option C. Secondary syphilis: Secondary syphilis is characterized by systemic manifestations such as skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions and is not related to Kassowitz's rule.

 

Option D. Latent syphilis: Latent syphilis refers to a stage where no symptoms are present but the infection is still systemic. Kassowitz's rule is not associated with latent syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kassowitz rule states that the likelihood of congenital syphilis infection decreases with each successive pregnancy in a woman with untreated syphilis.

 

Ref: Page no 343, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which part of the placenta is attached to the maternal side? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decidua basalis

 

Explanation

 

The decidua is the modified endometrium of the uterus that forms in preparation for and during pregnancy. It plays a crucial role in the implantation and support of the developing fetus.

 

Decidua Basalis: This is the part of the decidua that lies directly beneath the implanted embryo and forms the maternal part of the placenta. It is the region where the trophoblasts invade to establish the placental attachment to the maternal endometrium. It supports the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Decidua Parietalis: This is the part of the decidua that lines the remainder of the uterine cavity that is not involved in the implantation site. It is essentially the peripheral part of the endometrium.

 

Option C. Decidua Capsularis: This part of the decidua surrounds the embryo and eventually fuses with the decidua parietalis as the embryo grows, obliterating the uterine cavity.

 

Option D. Chorionic Plate: This is the fetal side of the placenta, consisting of the chorionic villi and other fetal tissues. It is not part of the maternal endometrium.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The decidua basalis is the part of the decidua that attaches to the maternal side of the placenta, facilitating the exchange of nutrients and waste between the mother and the fetus.
  • The decidua has three distinct regions based on their location and function in relation to the implanted embryo.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.
